name: Count the number of instances of three identical digits on a four-digit digital  clock
description:
On a digital clock showing `00:00` to `23:59` and given a start time and end time at [unix time](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time) integers as seconds elapsed since the epoch at 00:00:00 UTC Thursday, 1 January 1970, return the number of instances where the clock will will display exactly 3 of the same integer.

For example:
```ruby
# function returns 0 because the clock would have only read 00:00 and there are 4 of the same integer
three_identical_digits(0, 0)
#=> 0

# function returns 1 because the clock would have read 00:01 and there are exactly 3 0s
three_identical_digits(60, 60)
#=> 1

# function returns 1 because the clock would have read 00:01 for the entire duration and there are exactly 3 0s
three_identical_digits(65, 77)
#=> 1

# function returns 1 because the clock would have read both 00:00 and 00:01 for the entire duration and there are exactly 3 0s in the 2nd time on the clock
three_identical_digits(59, 77)
#=> 1

# function returns 2 because the clock would have read 00:00, 00:01, and 00:02 for the entire duration and there are exactly 3 0s in the 2nd and 3rd time on the clock
three_identical_digits(59, 125)
#=> 2

# function returns 76 because the clock would have 76 instances where the clock would display exactly 3 of the same integer in a 24 hour period
three_identical_digits(0, 86_340)
#= 76

# function returns 152 because the clock would have 152 instances where the clock would display exactly 3 of the same integer in the 48 hour period of the day before the epoch and the day after the epoch
three_identical_digits(-86_400, 86_340)
#= 152
```
